snippet: Abortion rights activists are seizing on the crisis to push back against conservative lawmakers who want to toughen already stringent limits.
abstract: Growing number of reports of Brazilian babies being born with condition known as microcephaly has kindled debate in country over its extremely prohibitive abortion laws; legal scholars are mounting case to make it legal for women to seek abortions in cases of microcephaly, and abortion rights activists are using crisis to criticize conservative lawmakers who have sought to make country's already restrictive laws even more stringent.

byline.contributor: Catherine Saint Louis contributed reporting from New York, Anna Jean Kaiser from Rio de Janeiro, and Paula Moura from São Paulo, Brazil.

lead_paragraph: Abortion rights activists are seizing on the crisis to push back against conservative lawmakers who want to toughen already stringent limits.

headline.main: Surge of Zika Virus Has Brazilians Re-examining Strict Abortion Laws
headline.print_headline: Zika Reignites Battle in Brazil Over Abortion
